questions.text: During a rural health camp screening in India, a 6-year-old boy is evaluated for developmental delay and unusual skeletal features. His parents report that he has a history of frequent eye and vision issues. A genetic enzymatic defect is suspected. Which condition is associated with a defect in the enzyme cystathionine synthase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Homocystinuria

 

Option C:

 

  • Congenital homocystinuria is due to defect in cystathionine beta Synthase deficiency → causes elevated plasma levels of methionine and homocysteine→ increased excretion of methionine and homocysteine in urine and Plasma cysteine is markedly reduced.
  • C/F-Mental retardation, ectopia lentis, thrombosis and charlie chaplin gait.
  • Cyanide-nitroprusside test is positive in urine, urinary excretion of homocysteine is more than 300 mg/24 h and plasma homocysteine and methionine levels are increased.
  • Treatment: Diet low in methionine and rich in cysteine. In few cases, pyridoxal phosphate given in large quantities (500 mg).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules due to mutation of SLC6A19 gene encodes the transporter protein (B0AT1) seen in Intestine and renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine. Due to deficiency of Tryptophan, Niacin is not produced and so, the presentation is similar to Pellagra.

 

Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream  → accumulation of cystine in urine forms crystals and stones → leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis and obstruction of urine flow →c/f- severe, sudden flank pain, blood and WBC in urine, fever, and finally renal failure.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionine deficiency, patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine synthase is an enzyme critical in the metabolism of methionine, converting homocysteine to cystathionine. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to homocystinuria, a disorder characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine, which can result in developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and ocular issues.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

questions.text: Which group among the following is responsible for buffering activity of proteins at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imidazole group

 

Option D:

 

The imidazole group, which is part of the histidine amino acid side chain, has significant buffering capacity at physiological pH (around 7.4). This is because the pKa of the imidazole group is close to the physiological pH, allowing it to effectively donate or accept protons, thereby contributing to buffering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sulfhydryl group - Present in cysteine, important for forming disulfide bonds, but not primarily known for buffering.

 

Option B: Indole group - Found in tryptophan, contributes to the protein's structural and functional aspects but lacks significant buffering capacity.

 

Option C: Phenyl group - Part of phenylalanine, contributes to hydrophobic interactions in proteins but does not have a buffering role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Only amino acid whose pKa value (6.1) is nearby physiological pH (7.4) is Histidine (Imidazole group), due to which it has buffering activity at physiological pH.

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 28.

choices.text: Defect of glycine cleavage complex
Accumulation of neurotoxic intermediates are seen

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is evaluated for severe mental retardation and recurrent seizures. His blood ammonia levels are normal, and there is no acidosis. Non-ketotic hyperglycinemia is diagnosed based on an elevated CSF/blood glycine ratio. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Effective management is available

 

Option B:


This condition is due to defect in glycine cleavage system, glycine level is increased in blood, urine, and CSF.

 

  • Severe mental retardation and seizures are seen and has no effective management.
  • Diagnosis: elevated CSF/blood glycine ratio which is important for genetic counselling.
  • Response to treatment is better in atypical NKH.
  • Hyperglycinemia is also seen in organic acidurias.


Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Defect of glycine cleavage complex: True, this is the underlying defect in non-ketotic hyperglycinemia.

 

Option C. Also known as glycine encephalopathy: True, this is another name for non-ketotic hyperglycinemia.

 

Option D. Accumulation of neurotoxic intermediates are seen: True, the accumulation of glycine and related compounds can lead to neurotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-ketotic hyperglycinemia, also known as glycine encephalopathy, is a rare genetic disorder caused by a defect in the glycine cleavage enzyme complex, leading to an accumulation of glycine and its neurotoxic intermediates. Unfortunately, effective management options are limited, and the disease often results in severe neurological deficits.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 301, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 213.

choices.text: Point A represents the region where the amino acid is deprotonated.
Point B represents a region of minimal buffering.
Point C represents the region where the net charge on the amino acid is zero.
Point D represents the pKa of the amino acid carboxyl group.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the titration curve of a nonpolar amino acid as shown in the graph with points labeled A to D. Which of the following statements correctly interprets the designated regions on the curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point C represents the region where the net charge on the amino acid is zero.

 

Option C:

 

Point C on a titration curve usually indicates the isoelectric point (pI) of an amino acid, where it has no net electric charge. This point is particularly useful in predicting the behavior of the amino acid under various pH conditions. At the isoelectric point, an amino acid neither moves towards the anode nor the cathode during electrophoresis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Point A represents the region where the amino acid is deprotonated: The amino acid is fully protonated at Point A due to low pH and abundance of protons in the solvent.

 

Option B: Point B represents a region of minimal buffering & Option D Point D represents the pK of the amino acid carboxyl group: Point B represents a region of maximum buffering, as does Point D which is the pKa of amino group.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The amino acid could be lysine. C represents the isoelectric point, or pI, and as such is midway between pK1 and pK2 for a nonpolar amino acid.
  • Lysine is a basic amino acid and has an ionizable side chain.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: p 6-9.

choices.text: The molecule carries no net charge
Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum
The buffering capacity of plasma proteins are mainly due to Histidine residue.
There is no mobility in an electric field

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the isoelectric pH (pI) of a molecule is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

 

Option B:

 

At its isoelectric pH, a molecule (such as an amino acid or protein) carries no net electrical charge, leading to minimal solubility in aqueous solutions due to reduced electrostatic interactions with water molecules. Contrary to increasing solubility and buffering capacity, both are actually at their minimum at the isoelectric point because the molecule has no net charge to donate or accept protons readily, thus reducing its ability to act as a buffer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The molecule carries no net charge - This is correct. At the isoelectric point, the number of positive charges equals the number of negative charges, resulting in no net charge.

 

Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue - This statement is generally correct as histidine residues in proteins, such as those in plasma proteins, play a significant role in buffering due to the pKa of the histidine side chain being close to physiological pH.

 

Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field - This is correct. Since the molecule has no net charge at its isoelectric point, it will not move towards either electrode in an electric field.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI).
  • At an isoelectric point, the amino acid will carry no net charge, all the groups are ionized but the charges will cancel each other. Hence, at isoelectric point, there is no mobility in an electrical field.
  • Solubility and buffering capacity will be minimum at isoelectric pH.
  • The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residue.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 20.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman in India presents with fever, left flank pain radiating to the leg, and acute urinary retention. She has a similar past episode six months ago. On examination, she's tender in the abdominal region and appears anemic. Urinalysis reveals RBCs, pus cells, WBC casts, hexagonal crystals, and amino acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystinuria

 

Option B:

                                

  • Patients with cystinuria cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream → accumulation of amino acid in urine.
  • As urine becomes more concentrated → excess cysteine forms crystals → lodge in bladder or kidneys.
  • Cystine combines with calcium → forms larger stones → block passage of urine → leads to infections - recurrent nephrolithiasis and obstruction of urine flow → c/f- severe, sudden flank pain, blood and WBC in urine, fever and finally renal failure.
  • Diagnostic tests: Sodium nitroprusside test; X-rays and CT of kidneys – To detect cystine stones.
  • Treatment: To increase cystine excretion by dietary sodium and protein restriction. Also, urine alkalinization improves cysteine solubility and severe cases need surgical intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cystinosis: This is a lysosomal storage disorder with accumulation of excess cystine crystals in eyes and kidneys. Due to mutation in the gene CTNS, which codes for the protein cystinosin, the lysosomal cystine transporter. Symptoms: excessive urination, poor growth, photophobia and renal failure by age 6.

 

Option C. Renal Fanconi syndrome: Caused by Cystinosis with loss of large amounts of salt and other minerals in urine. It is an example of RTA Type 2, characterized by increased urinary excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonate, phosphate and salt wasting.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency, presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of characteristic hexagonal crystals in the urine along with RBCs, pus cells, and WBC casts suggests a stone-forming condition. Cystinuria is a genetic disorder characterized by defective renal tubular reabsorption of certain amino acids including cystine, leading to the formation of cystine stones, which can manifest with urinary retention and flank pain due to obstruction.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 301-302.

questions.text: Garrod's tetrad refers to a group of four metabolic disorders. Which of the following options correctly lists these disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Alkaptonuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, Albinism

 

Option A:

 

Garrod's tetrad includes four inborn errors of metabolism that were initially described by Archibald Garrod. These are Alkaptonuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, and Albinism. Garrod is known for his pioneering work in the field of genetics and metabolism, and these disorders were among the first to be understood in the context of genetic inheritance and metabolic dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Alkaptonuria, Pentos Uria, Galactosemia, Albinism: While galactosemia is a well-known metabolic disorder, it is not part of Garrod's original tetrad.

 

Option C. Fructosuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, Albinism: Fructosuria is another metabolic condition but was not included in Garrod's tetrad.

 

Option D. Alkaptonuria, Pentos Uria, Cystinuria, Mucopolysaccharidosis: Mucopolysaccharidosis refers to a group of lysosomal storage diseases and is not part of Garrod's tetrad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Garrod’s tetrad includes

Cystinuria
Alkaptonuria
Albinism
Pentosuria

(Mnemonic- CAAP)

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive involuntary movements in her right hand and visual difficulties noted over the past year. Blood work reveals elevated serum homocysteine with normal liver, renal, thyroid function tests, and electrolytes. She responds favorably to high-dose pyridoxine and a methionine-restricted diet, with a noted improvement in dystonic movements after three months. What condition is most likely affecting this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Classical Homocystinuria

 

Option C:

 

  • Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • Clinical features: failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.
  • During pregnancy, it causes neural tube defects and pre-eclampsia.
  • Diagnosis: amino acid screen in urine and blood (homocysteine and methionine are elevated, cystine will be low), liver biopsy, enzyme assay, skeletal X-ray, skin fibroblast enzyme assay, standard ophthalmic testing, and genetic testing.
  • Treatment with high doses of pyridoxine, folic acid, B12 and betaine reduces homocysteine levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine.

 

Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream →accumulation of cystine in urine forms stones →leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis, obstruction, and finally renal failure.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency, patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, leading to elevated homocysteine levels. Treatment with high-dose pyridoxine (vitamin B6), a cofactor for the enzyme, can improve symptoms, and a methionine-restricted diet can help manage homocysteine levels. The improvement in dystonia with treatment supports this diagnosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a diet lacking in fresh produce presents with recurrent infections and bruising. Considering her dietary insufficiency and clinical signs of compromised antioxidant defense, which set of amino acids is essential for the synthesis of the key antioxidant, glutathione?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Glutamic acid, cysteine, glycine

 

Option C:

 

Glutathione is a tripeptide consisting of glutamic acid, cysteine, and glycine. It functions as a major antioxidant, particularly in the liver, where it helps to detoxify harmful compounds. In the context of this patient, a diet lacking in adequate nutrients may lead to a deficiency in one or more of the amino acids required for the synthesis of glutathione, compromising her antioxidant defense and contributing to her clinical presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glutamic acid, cystine, cysteine: Cystine is the oxidized dimer form of cysteine, and while it can be converted back to cysteine in the body, cystine itself is not directly used in glutathione synthesis.

 

Option B. Glutamic acid, alanine, glycine: Alanine is not a component of glutathione.

 

Option D. Glutamic acid, cysteine, valine: Valine is a branched-chain amino acid that is not involved in the synthesis of glutathione.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gamma glutamyl cysteinyl glycine (Tripeptide: - SH group of cysteine is active part / reducing agent of GSH) reduction of methemoglobin (Fe 3+) to normal Hb (Fe 2+)
  • It is involved in erythrocyte membrane integrity and in keeping enzymes in active state.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 44, 198.

choices.text: Glycine is an essential amino acid

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glycine is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Optically inactive

 

Option D:

 

  • Glycine is the simplest amino acid and has no asymmetric carbon atom. Therefore, it shows no optical activity.
  • Glycine is the only optically inactive amino acid. All other amino acids are optically active.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycine is not an essential amino acid; the human body can synthesize it.

 

Option B. Sulfur at the 4th position describes certain other amino acids like cysteine, but not glycine.

 

Option C. A guanidine group is characteristic of arginine, not glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycine is unique among amino acids because it has a hydrogen atom as its side chain, making it the simplest amino acid. This simplicity leads to its lack of a chiral centre, rendering it optically inactive, unlike most other amino acids that are optically active due to the presence of a chiral carbon atom.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p19.

questions.text: Creatinine is synthesized in the body through a process involving the breakdown of a specific amino acid. Which amino acid is primarily involved in the formation of creatinine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arginine

 

Option A:

 

Three amino acids from which Creatine and creatinine is synthesized are

 

  • Arginine
  • Glycine
  • Methionine

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lysine: While lysine is involved in many biochemical processes, it is not directly involved in the synthesis of creatinine.

 

Option C. Histamine: Histamine is a biogenic amine derived from histidine and is not involved in creatinine synthesis.

 

Option D. Leucine: Leucine is a branched-chain amino acid involved in protein synthesis and energy production but not in the formation of creatinine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine is formed from the breakdown of creatine phosphate in muscle and to a smaller extent from the diet. Creatine itself is synthesized from the amino acids arginine, glycine, and methionine. Arginine plays a crucial role in the initial step of creatine synthesis, which ultimately leads to the formation of creatinine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p320.

questions.text: Polyamines are organic compounds that play a critical role in cellular processes. Which of the following is an example of a polyamine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spermidine

 

Option A:

 

  • Polyamines are putrescine, spermidine and spermine.
  • They are aliphatic amines.
  • Humans synthesize about 0.5 mmol of spermine per day.
  • They are synthesized from Ornithine.
  • Biochemical Functions of Polyamines
    • They are required for protein biosynthesis.
    • Other functions: Cell proliferation, stabilization of ribosomes and DNA, synthesis of DNA and RNA, protection of DNA against depurination etc.
    • Its concentration is increased in cancer tissues.
    • They are growth factors in cell culture systems.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Arginine: An amino acid, not a polyamine, although it is involved in the synthesis of polyamines.

 

Option C. Histamine: A biogenic amine derived from histidine, involved in immune responses and not classified as a polyamine.

 

Option D. Lysine: An essential amino acid important for protein synthesis, not a polyamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spermidine is a polyamine involved in cellular metabolism and is found in ribosomes and living tissues. It plays a role in cellular growth, proliferation, and differentiation.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 229.

questions.text: Which amino acid is the precursor for the synthesis of nitric oxide (NO)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arginine

 

Option A:

 

  • Nitric oxide is synthesized from arginine by enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS) which contains heme, FAD, FMN and tetrahydrobiopterin.
  • The enzyme utilizes NADPH and molecular oxygen.
  • Calmodulin is required to modulate its activity.
  • The guanidino nitrogen of arginine is incorporated into NO˙ 🡪 from the molecular oxygen, one atom is added to NO˙ and the other into citrulline.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Alanine - Alanine is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

 

Option C: Glycine - Glycine is also not a precursor for NO production.

 

Option D: Lysine - Lysine does not participate in the biosynthesis of NO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from the amino acid arginine. The enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS) catalyzes the conversion of arginine to NO and citrulline. This reaction is fundamental in various physiological processes, including vasodilation, neurotransmission, and immune response.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 227.

questions.text: Amino acids present in human proteins are predominantly:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-forms

 

Option A:

 

In proteins, amino acids are almost exclusively in the L-form. This stereospecificity is crucial for the proper folding and function of proteins. The L-form of amino acids is the only form that is incorporated into the polypeptide chains during protein synthesis in humans and most other life forms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: D-forms - This option is incorrect because D-forms of amino acids are not typically incorporated into proteins in humans.

 

Option C: Mostly D form - This is not accurate; human proteins are made up of L-form amino acids, not D-form.

 

Option D: D and L form - While both forms exist in nature, only L-form amino acids are incorporated into proteins during biosynthesis in humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physical properties of Human amino acids:

 

  • All are L-ɑ amino acids
  • Optically active (except glycine)
  • At their pI, they have buffering activity. (Histidine has buffering action at our physiological pH of 7.0).

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 29.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby boy presents with a 6-day history of fever, cough, breathing difficulty, and Kussmaul respiration. On examination, he appears lethargic and dehydrated, and the mother reports his urine has a distinctive cheesy odor. Urine organic acid analysis indicates increased excretion of 3-hydroxybutyric acid and moderate levels of 3-hydroxy-isovaleric acid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isovaleric acidemia

 

Option A:

 

  • Metabolic disorders of branched-chain amino acid catabolism include hypervalinemia, maple syrup urine disease, intermittent branched-chain ketonuria, isovaleric acidemia and methylmalonic aciduria.
  • In isovaleric acidemia, due to the defective function of enzyme isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase, the ingestion of protein-rich foods will elevate the diacylation product of isovaleryl-CoA, the isovalerate.
  • C/F: Vomiting, acidosis, coma, and excretion of isovalerate gives cheesy odour to urine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. C/F: mild mental retardation, Cabbage like odour in urine, hypoglycemia liver failure and finally death occurs

 

Option C. Phenylketonuria: defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase, gives mousy or musty odour.

 

Option D. Maple syrup urine disease:  Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues. The urine has the maple syrup odour / burnt sugar smell with development of metabolic acidosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isovaleric acidemia is characterized by the inability to properly break down the amino acid leucine, leading to the accumulation of isovaleric acid and related metabolites, including 3-hydroxybutyric acid and 3-hydroxy-isovaleric acid. The distinctive "sweaty feet" or cheesy odor of the urine is a classic clinical clue.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 309-312.

questions.text: In a study group session focusing on stereochemistry in biological molecules, a debate arises regarding the chiral properties of amino acids. One of the points of discussion is whether tyrosine, known for its aromatic ring and role in protein structure, possesses double chirality. Is the statement "Amino acid with double chiral centers is Tyrosine" true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) False

 

Option B:

 

Tyrosine is an amino acid that contains only one chiral center, which is the alpha carbon atom common to all standard amino acids (except glycine, which is achiral). The presence of a single chiral center does not make tyrosine a compound with double chirality. Amino acids like threonine and isoleucine have two chiral centers, making them capable of having more stereoisomers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The α-carbon of amino acids has four different groups attached to it and so is a chiral or asymmetric carbon
  • All amino acids have one chiral carbon, except-

 

  1. Amino acid with no chiral carbon → Glycine
  2. Amino acid with two chiral centers → Threonine & isoleucine

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 29.

questions.text: At a Health fair, a nutritionist sets up an interactive booth focusing on amino acids and their derivatives, highlighting their roles in nutrition and health. One of the informational posters prompts visitors to match lesser-known names of amino acid derivatives with their more common terms. A visitor, intrigued by the challenge, points to "N-Methyl Glycine" on the poster. She asks the nutritionist for its commonly known name. How should the nutritionist respond?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Sarcosine

 

Option B:

 

  • The biosynthesis and catabolism of sarcosine (N-methyl glycine) occur in mitochondria.
  • Formation of sarcosine from dimethyl glycine is catalyzed by the flavoprotein dimethyl glycine dehydrogenase, which requires reduced pteroyl penta glutamate (TPG).

 

 

  • Traces of sarcosine can also be formed by methylation of glycine, catalyzed by glycine N-methyltransferase.
  • Catabolism of sarcosine to glycine, catalyzed by the flavoprotein sarcosine dehydrogenase, requires reduced pteroyl penta glutamate.

­­­­

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ergothioneine: This is a derivative of histidine, not related to N-Methyl Glycine.

 

Option C. Carnosine: This dipeptide consists of beta-alanine and histidine, differing significantly from N-Methyl Glycine.

 

Option D. Betaine: Derived from choline, betaine serves as a methyl donor in various biochemical processes but is not synonymous with N-Methyl Glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

N-Methyl Glycine is more commonly known as sarcosine. It is a derivative of glycine, where a methyl group is added to the amino acids nitrogen atom. Sarcosine plays various roles in biological systems, including in metabolism and nutrition.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 284.

choices.text: An increase of blood urea and creatinine
An increase of blood glucose and ketone bodies
An increase of blood T3 and T4
An increase of urine urea and creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following best describes azotemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An increase of blood urea and creatinine

 

Option A.

 

  • Increase in the blood levels of NPN (non-protein nitrogen) is referred to as azotemia.
  • It is the hallmark of kidney failure.
  • BUN/Creatinine ratio is used as a discriminator between prerenal and postrenal azotemia.
  • A normal adult on a normal diet has a ratio between 12 – 20 mg BUN/mg of creatinine.
  • Lower ratios: acute renal tubular necrosis, low protein intake, starvation and severe liver disease.
  • High plasma urea with normal creatinine and high BUN/creatinine ratio:  indicates prerenal azotemia.
  • High ratios with high urea and creatinine: post-renal obstruction or prerenal azotemia superimposed on CKD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. An increase of blood glucose and ketone bodies: Diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option C. An increase of blood T3 and T4: Hyperthyroidism.

 

Option D. An increase of blood urea and creatinine: CKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azotemia is characterized by an increase in the levels of nitrogen-containing compounds in the blood, particularly urea and creatinine, which are waste products typically filtered out by the kidneys. An elevation of these substances in the blood often indicates impaired kidney function or reduced renal filtration capacity.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 418.
